doc.title: hmmer

description.text: HMMER is an implementation of profile HMM methods for sensitive database searches using multiple sequence alignments as queries.

doc.reference: Eddy, S. R. (1998). Profile hidden Markov models. Bioinformatics, 14:755-763.
Eddy, S. R. (2008). A probabilistic model of local sequence alignment that simplifies statistical significance estimation. PLoS Comput. Biol., 4:e1000069

description.text: Build a profile HMM from an input multiple alignment

interface.label:
Forcing an alphabet in input alignment?
Autodetection Protein DNA RNA
The alphabet type (amino, DNA, or RNA) is autodetected by default, by looking at the composition of the msafile. Autodetection is normally quite reliable, but occasionally alphabet type may be ambiguous and autodetection can fail (for instance, on tiny toy alignments of just a few residues). To avoid this, or to increase robustness in automated analysis pipelines, you may specify the alphabet type of msafile with these options.
Protein: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are proteins. By default, alphabet type is autodetected from looking at the residue composition.
DNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are DNAs.
RNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are RNAs.

xhtml:div.label:
Name the HMM (-n)?
Name the new profile. The default is to use the name of the alignment (if one is present in the msafile, or, failing that, the name of the hmmfile. If msafile contains more than one alignment, -n doesn't work, and every alignment must have a name annotated in the msafile (as in Stockholm #=GF ID annotation).

Re_save annotated, possibly modified MSA to 'file', in Stockholm format. (-O)?
After each model is constructed, resave annotated, possibly modified source alignments to a file in Stockholm format. The alignments are annotated with a reference annotation line indicating which columns were assigned as consensus, and sequences are annotated with what relative sequence weights were assigned. Some residues of the alignment may have been shifted to accommodate restrictions of the Plan7 profile architecture, which disallows transitions between insert and delete states..

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These options control how consensus columns are defined in an alignment.

xhtml:div.label:
Quickly and heuristically determine the architecture of the model (fast) ?
Yes No
Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as opposed to gaps. (See the --symfrac option.) This is the default.

Sets sym fraction controlling for the --fast model construction algorithm, (symfrac) ?
Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions). Setting this to 0.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases. Setting it to 1.0 means that only columns that have no gap characters at all will be assigned as consensus.

Tag sequence as a fragment, (fragthresh)?
Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length L is less than a fraction x times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

Alternative relative sequence weighting strategies?
Henikoff position-based weighting scheme (wpb) Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm (wgsc) BLOSUM filtering algorithm to weight the sequences (wblosum) Turn off all sequence weighting (wnone) Personal weights in file. Give file in next parameter
HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation. For example, two identical sequences would typically each receive half the weight that one sequence would. These options control which algorithm gets used.
wnp: Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
wgsc: Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].
wblosum: Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915, 1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
wnone: No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight

Set identity cutoff for BLOSUM filtering algorithm option (wid)?
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62. Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1

Alternate effective sequence weighting strategies?
Adjust effective sequence weighting to achieve relative entropy target (eent) Effective sequence weighting is weighting of single linkage clusters (eclust) No effective sequence weighting: just use number of sequence (enone) Personal setting of effective sequence weighting for all models to value
After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number, eff nseq. This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that. The default entropy weighting method (--eent) reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position. The target relative entropy is controlled by a two-parameter function, where the two parameters are settable with --ere and --esigma.
--eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default.
--eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it's for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.
--enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models

Set personal effective sequence weighting for all models to value (eset)?
Explicitly set the effective sequence number for all models to value

For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set minimum relative entropy/position to value (ere)?
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target to value. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set sigma parameter to value (esigma)?
Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

For single linkage clustering: set fractional identity cutoff to value (eid)?
Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores require three short random sequence simulations.

xhtml:div.label:
Lengt of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmL)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

Number of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmN)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

Lengt of sequences for Viterbi Gumbel mu fit (EvL)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

Number of sequences for Viterbi Gumbel mu fit (EvN)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.

Lengt of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfL)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.

Number of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfN)?
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.

Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)?
Enter a value > 0 and < 1. Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

Set random number seed (seed)?
Seed the random number generator with the value, an integer >= 0. If the value is nonzero, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results. If the number is 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command. The default seed is 42.
Use a Laplace +1 prior Yes No

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The alphabet type (amino, DNA, or RNA) is autodetected by default, by looking at the composition of the msafile. Autodetection is normally quite reliable, but occasionally alphabet type may be ambiguous and autodetection can fail (for instance, on tiny toy alignments of just a few residues). To avoid this, or to increase robustness in automated analysis pipelines, you may specify the alphabet type of msafile with these options.
Protein: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are proteins. By default, alphabet type is autodetected from looking at the residue composition.
DNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are DNAs.
RNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are RNAs.

Name the new profile. The default is to use the name of the alignment (if one is present in the msafile, or, failing that, the name of the hmmfile. If msafile contains more than one alignment, -n doesn't work, and every alignment must have a name annotated in the msafile (as in Stockholm #=GF ID annotation).

After each model is constructed, resave annotated, possibly modified source alignments to a file in Stockholm format. The alignments are annotated with a reference annotation line indicating which columns were assigned as consensus, and sequences are annotated with what relative sequence weights were assigned. Some residues of the alignment may have been shifted to accommodate restrictions of the Plan7 profile architecture, which disallows transitions between insert and delete states..
Define consensus columns as those that have a fraction >= symfrac of residues as opposed to gaps. (See the --symfrac option.) This is the default.

Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Define the residue fraction threshold necessary to define a consensus column when using the --fast option. The default is 0.5. The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions). Setting this to 0.0 means that every alignment column will be assigned as consensus, which may be useful in some cases. Setting it to 1.0 means that only columns that have no gap characters at all will be assigned as consensus.

Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length L is less than a fraction x times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation. For example, two identical sequences would typically each receive half the weight that one sequence would. These options control which algorithm gets used.
wnp: Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
wgsc: Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

wblosum: Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915, 1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
wnone: No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62. Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1

After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number, eff nseq. This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that. The default entropy weighting method (--eent) reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position. The target relative entropy is controlled by a two-parameter function, where the two parameters are settable with --ere and --esigma.
--eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default.

--eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it's for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

--enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models
Explicitly set the effective sequence number for all models to value
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target to value. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.
Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi filter E-values. Default is 200.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100.
Enter a value > 0. Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200.
Enter a value > 0 and < 1. Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

Seed the random number generator with the value, an integer >= 0. If the value is nonzero, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results. If the number is 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command. The default seed is 42.

parameter.name: alignfile
parameter.prompt: Aligned sequences File

parameter.name: alphabet
parameter.prompt: Forcing an alphabet in input alignment

format.code: ("", " " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: The alphabet type (amino, DNA, or RNA) is autodetected by default, by looking at the composition of the msafile. Autodetection is normally quite reliable, but occasionally alphabet type may be ambiguous and autodetection can fail (for instance, on tiny toy alignments of just a few residues). To avoid this, or to increase robustness in automated analysis pipelines, you may specify the alphabet type of msafile with these options.
Protein: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are proteins. By default, alphabet type is autodetected from looking at the residue composition.
DNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are DNAs.
RNA: Specify that all sequences in seqfile are RNAs.

parameter.name: symfrac
parameter.prompt: Sets sym fraction controlling for the --fast model construction algorithm, (symfrac)

format.code: ( "" , " --symfrac " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

The symbol fraction in each column is calculated after taking relative sequence weighting into account, and ignoring gap characters corresponding to ends of sequence fragments (as opposed to internal insertions/deletions). Setting it to 1.0 means that only columns that have no gap characters at all will be assigned as consensus.

parameter.name: fragthresh
parameter.prompt: Tag sequence as a fragment, (fragthresh)

format.code: ( "" , " --fragthresh " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. We only want to count terminal gaps as deletions if the aligned sequence is known to be full-length, not if it is a fragment (for instance, because only part of it was sequenced). HMMER uses a simple rule to infer fragments: if the sequence length L is less than a fraction x times the mean sequence length of all the sequences in the alignment, then the sequence is handled as a fragment. The default is 0.5.

parameter.name: relativeWeight
parameter.prompt: Alternative relative sequence weighting strategies

velem.label: Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm (wgsc)
BLOSUM filtering algorithm to weight the sequences (wblosum)
Personal weights in file. Give file in next parameter

comment.text: HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation. For example, two identical sequences would typically each receive half the weight that one sequence would. These options control which algorithm gets used.
wnp: Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
wgsc: Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

wblosum: Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915, 1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
wnone: No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight

interface.label:
Alternative relative sequence weighting strategies?
Henikoff position-based weighting scheme (wpb) Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm (wgsc) BLOSUM filtering algorithm to weight the sequences (wblosum) Turn off all sequence weighting (wnone) Personal weights in file. Give file in next parameter
HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation. For example, two identical sequences would typically each receive half the weight that one sequence would. These options control which algorithm gets used.
wnp: Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
wgsc: Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].
wblosum: Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915, 1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
wnone: No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: HMMER uses an ad hoc sequence weighting algorithm to downweight closely related sequences and upweight distantly related ones. This has the effect of making models less biased by uneven phylogenetic representation. For example, two identical sequences would typically each receive half the weight that one sequence would. These options control which algorithm gets used.
wnp: Use the Henikoff position-based sequence weighting scheme [Henikoff and Henikoff, J. Mol. Biol. 243:574, 1994]. This is the default.
wgsc: Use the Gerstein/Sonnhammer/Chothia weighting algorithm [Gerstein et al, J. Mol. Biol. 235:1067, 1994].

wblosum: Use the same clustering scheme that was used to weight data in calculating BLOSUM subsitution matrices [Henikoff and Henikoff, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci 89:10915, 1992]. Sequences are single-linkage clustered at an identity threshold (default 0.62; see --wid) and within each cluster of c sequences, each sequence gets relative weight 1/c.
wnone: No relative weights. All sequences are assigned uniform weight

parameter.name: wgiven
parameter.prompt: Personal weights in file

parameter.name: wid
parameter.prompt: Set identity cutoff for BLOSUM filtering algorithm option (wid)

format.code: ("", " --wid " + str(value))[value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62. Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1

interface.label:
Set identity cutoff for BLOSUM filtering algorithm option (wid)?
Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62. Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the identity threshold used by single-linkage clustering when using --wblosum. Invalid with any other weighting scheme. Default is 0.62. Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1

parameter.name: effectiveWeight
parameter.prompt: Alternate effective sequence weighting strategies

velem.label: Adjust effective sequence weighting to achieve relative entropy target (eent)
Effective sequence weighting is weighting of single linkage clusters (eclust)
No effective sequence weighting: just use number of sequence (enone)
Personal setting of effective sequence weighting for all models to value

comment.text: After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number, eff nseq. This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that. The default entropy weighting method (--eent) reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position. The target relative entropy is controlled by a two-parameter function, where the two parameters are settable with --ere and --esigma.
--eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default.

--eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it's for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

--enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models

interface.label:
Alternate effective sequence weighting strategies?
Adjust effective sequence weighting to achieve relative entropy target (eent) Effective sequence weighting is weighting of single linkage clusters (eclust) No effective sequence weighting: just use number of sequence (enone) Personal setting of effective sequence weighting for all models to value

This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that. The default entropy weighting method (--eent) reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position. The target relative entropy is controlled by a two-parameter function, where the two parameters are settable with --ere and --esigma.
--eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default.
--eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it's for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.
--enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: After relative weights are determined, they are normalized to sum to a total effective sequence number, eff nseq. This number may be the actual number of sequences in the alignment, but it is almost always smaller than that. The default entropy weighting method (--eent) reduces the effective sequence number to reduce the information content (relative entropy, or average expected score on true homologs) per consensus position. The target relative entropy is controlled by a two-parameter function, where the two parameters are settable with --ere and --esigma.
--eent: Adjust effective sequence number to achieve a specific relative entropy per position (see --ere). This is the default.

--eclust: Set effective sequence number to the number of single-linkage clusters at a specific identity threshold (see --eid). This option is not recommended; it's for experiments evaluating how much better --eent is.

--enone: Turn off effective sequence number determination and just use the actual number of sequences. One reason you might want to do this is to try to maximize the relative entropy/position of your model, which may be useful for short models

parameter.name: eset
parameter.prompt: Set personal effective sequence weighting for all models to value (eset)

comment.text: Explicitly set the effective sequence number for all models to value

interface.label:
Set personal effective sequence weighting for all models to value (eset)?
Explicitly set the effective sequence number for all models to value

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Explicitly set the effective sequence number for all models to value

parameter.name: ere
parameter.prompt: For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set minimum relative entropy/position to value (ere)

comment.text: Set the minimum relative entropy/position target to value. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

interface.label:
For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set minimum relative entropy/position to value (ere)?
Set the minimum relative entropy/position target to value. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the minimum relative entropy/position target to value. Requires --eent. Default depends on the sequence alphabet; for protein sequences, it is 0.59 bits/position.

parameter.name: esigma
parameter.prompt: For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set sigma parameter to value (esigma)

format.code: ( "" , " --esigma " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

interface.label:
For personal adjustment of effective sequence weighting: set sigma parameter to value (esigma)?
Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the minimum relative entropy contributed by an entire model alignment, over its whole length. This has the effect of making short models have higher relative entropy per position than --ere alone would give. The default is 45.0 bits.

parameter.name: eid
parameter.prompt: For single linkage clustering: set fractional identity cutoff to value (eid)

format.code: ( "" , " --eid " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

interface.label:
For single linkage clustering: set fractional identity cutoff to value (eid)?
Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Enter a value >= 0 and <= 1. Sets the fractional pairwise identity cutoff used by single linkage clustering with the --eclust option. The default is 0.62.

comment.text: The location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV filter scores, Viterbi filter scores, and Forward scores require three short random sequence simulations.

parameter.name: EmL
parameter.prompt: Lengt of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmL)

format.code: ( "" , " --EmL " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Enter a value > 0. Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV filter E-values. Default is 200.

interface.label:
Lengt of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmL)?

parameter.prompt: Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)

format.code: ( "" , " --Eft " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Enter a value > 0 and < 1. Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

interface.label:
Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)?
Enter a value > 0 and < 1. Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.prompt: Set random number seed (seed)

format.code: ( "" , " --seed " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: Seed the random number generator with the value, an integer >= 0. If the value is nonzero, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results. If the number is 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command. The default seed is 42.

interface.label:
Set random number seed (seed)?
Seed the random number generator with the value, an integer >= 0. If the value is nonzero, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results. If the number is 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command. The default seed is 42.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Seed the random number generator with the value, an integer >= 0. If the value is nonzero, any stochastic simulations will be reproducible; the same command will give the same results. If the number is 0, the random number generator is seeded arbitrarily, and stochastic simulations will vary from run to run of the same command. The default seed is 42.
